page.title: 18Owl House and The Pottery
page.content: { The Owl House}is a tourist attraction in{Lamberhurst}mainly because of the beautiful{gardens,}created by the Marchioness of Dufferin. However, the cottage, which is over 500 years old, was the centre for wool smugglers who operated at night and their warning hoots gave the name "Owlers". The chimney is said to be the crookedest in Kent. At{Hook Green,}a local man has converted old tractor sheds into his own{pottery.}He and his wife produce a fine range of domestic pottery; practical, yet nonetheless very attractive. The powdered clay is delivered and then the potter makes up his own mixture to suit the plates, dishes, beakers, jugs or teapots that he hand throws on the electric wheel. Gas, electric or wood kilns fire the clay before and after glazing. Sales are made from within the pottery.
